results.title: We the jury
results.creator_credit: Triptych Films, Debra Annear and Jo Lane
results.brief_description: This program clearly defines the procedures involved in selecting a jury to serve in a criminal trial. The Victorian example is used to explain the various steps of jury service including: jury selection, how jurors may be challenged, how jurors may be excused form serving and swearing in a jury. Interviews with jurors, a judge and other legal personnel further explain the reasons behind the procedures, providing an insight into the role of the jury. Suitable for middle Secondary - Tertiary level students.

results.title: We stop here
results.brief_description: Describes life on the Aboriginal reserve of Palm Island in Queensland. Old men from the Dyirbal tribe tell stories of the massacres and poisoning of their people when they first came in contact with the white settlers.

results.title: We sing more than we cry
results.brief_description: For two centuries Acadians have been reliving the legacy of exile left to them by their ancestors in 1755. Here, following a brief look at that tragic legacy, are expressions in word, song and music of the present-day struggle to maintain a viable cultural identity. They include the bitter outpourings of Acadian youth, and the humorous music of happy old-timers who sing and fiddle in the traditional style of Acadian folk music. The theme song is performed by well-known singer Edith Butler, herself an Acadian.

results.title: We see it like this (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Eurfron Gwynne Jones
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children Growing Up”.
In any form of self expression there is a development which is related to intellectual growth, physical growth and experience. To explore this, the program looks at the way in which children of different ages express their ideas of friendship.

results.title: We of the West Riding
results.creator_credit: Greenpark Productions, Ralph Keene and Ken Annakin
results.brief_description: Yorkshire, its people, factories and wild moorland scenery. We are shown the country in which the Bronte sisters were born and its influence on their famous novel. Finally the chorus of the Chapel Choir sings the Hallelujah Chorus from Handel’s “Messiah”.

results.title: We of the never never [DVD] (A)
results.creator_credit: Adams Packer Films, Film Corporation of Western Australia, Greg Tepper, John B Murray and Igor Auzins
results.brief_description: Published in 1908, Jeannie Gunn’s autobiographical novel, “We of the Never Never”, chronicled the tough life she and her husband Aeneas shared while managing one of Australia’s largest cattle stations, Elsie Station on the remote Roper River in the Northern Territory. Adapted from this classic Australian novel, the film tells the story of how Jeannie adapts to the harsh and isolated station life, how she wins acceptance from the station’s disapproving stockmen and how she learns from and befriends some of the indigenous Australians she encounters there. Cast includes Angela Punch-McGregor and Arthur Dignam. Music composed by Peter Best (Awards: AFI Award 1982 Gary Hansen for cinematography.).

results.title: We need to talk: employer/employee communication
results.brief_description: This business management resource has been designed by professionals with people management experience in a variety of industries including finance, manufacturing, hospitality and information services. The program is intended for use in a self study or group situation and details seven steps that comprise a successful agenda for meetings, as well as key counselling techniques. These steps and techniques are put into practice through two typical workplace scenarios.

results.title: "We need pockets. Please and THANK you"
results.material_description:
Digital screen recording from @the_female_lead’s Instagram.
Song and video by @hebontheweb, inspired by @meri.pocket, produced by @iamfredcox.
results.brief_description: Dedicated to amplifying women’s voices and advocating for female equality, The Female Lead teamed up with Heather Chelan and Fred Cox for ‘We need pockets’. Inspired by teenage activist Taarini Saraf’s @meri_pocket, the collaboration exposes the ridiculous practice of incorporating fake pockets into jeans for aesthetics rather than practical wearability.
results.title_for_label: “We need pockets. Please and THANK you”
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Dedicated to amplifying women’s voices and advocating for female equality, The Female Lead teamed up with Heather Chelan and Fred Cox for ‘We need pockets’. Inspired by teenage activist Taarini Saraf’s @meri.pocket, the collaboration exposes the ridiculous practice of incorporating fake pockets into jeans for aesthetics rather than practical wearability.
description_for_label:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Dedicated to amplifying women’s voices and advocating for female equality, The Female Lead teamed up with Heather Chelan and Fred Cox for ‘We need pockets’. Inspired by teenage activist Taarini Saraf’s @meri.pocket, the collaboration exposes the ridiculous practice of incorporating fake pockets into jeans for aesthetics rather than practical wearability.

results.title: We live by the river
results.creator_credit: BBC Film Unit, Richard Crawston and Jack Howells
results.brief_description: The atmosphere, the spirit and the pride of London, seen through the eyes of two young boys from the south side (right bank) of the River Thames. They set off one morning to see, for the first time, the more famous part of London, with its many historic buildings, its parks and shops, which lie on the opposite bank. The story is told through scenes and music only - no commentary. Photographed by Clifford Hornby.
